Hi Phill, assigning an (x,y) coordinate to nodes is indeed unusual in NEA=
T.  However, my guess (without being 100% sure) is that it will not have an=
 overall harmful effect, so I don't believe it will cause a major problem w=
ith the algorithm.  However, my main question is what advantage you see for=
 giving nodes an (x,y) position?  I'm not sure that it adds anything useful=
, in particular the x component.  While I do see a role for the y position =
in identifying recurrence, I am not sure the purpose of x?

In any case, I =
don't think the issue of whether adding a new node to a previously disabled=
 connection is going to have major consequences regardless of exactly how s=
uch a situation is handled.  If you just end up doing nothing in that case =
(and then perhaps trying a different mutation instead) the system should mo=
re or less function without any major problems.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogrou=
ps.com, "Phill" <feelipg@...> wrote:
>
> Hi guys - great group!
> 
> I've s=
earched the group in case these questions have already been answered - apol=
ogies if I missed them!
> 
> I have added my own implementation of NEAT to =
my AL framework (I'm a hobbyist) - like most people who implement their own=
 I've done this so I can fully understand the algorithm.
> 
> I've read Ken=
's paper, stepped through the original code and also read the chapter in AI=
 Techniques for Game Programming along with other articles/blogs etc.  My i=
mplementation seems to run pretty well - although I haven't compared it's p=
erformance (in terms of efficiency at finding solutions) to any other imple=
mentations.
> 
> Although I treat both Node Genes and Connection Genes as i=
nnovations for completeness - the system doesn't make use of the innovation=
 IDs for nodes - as to me an innovation resulting from a new node is the as=
sociated connection innovations created.  Something makes me think this may=
 be a mistake and I'm missing something.  However a Connection is defined b=
y the two nodes it connects - and a Node is defined by it's position in a 0=
-1 x 0-1 2d space.  This means that nodes are considered the same if they o=
ccupy the same space (x,y) - there is no concept of a unique NodeID.  When =
a Node is created during a mutation it is given the X,Y position half way b=
etween nodes defining the connection it is splitting.  It is possible that =
in the future I will add other attributes to Nodes which will be taken into=
 account for Node equality too - but for now it is just X,Y.
> 
> So I have=
 two questions:
> 
> 1)  When a Connection is disabled and then re-enabled =
in the future from crossover - if this connection is subsequently split aga=
in by a new node mutation - my implementation effectively looses this mutat=
ion because the new node and connections have already been added to the gen=
otype in the original mutation.  So all that happens is the connection is d=
isabled - again.  Mat's book mentions this and implies that a new innovatio=
n should be created - which i guess means the network ends up with an addit=
ional node?  I couldn't see where this explicitly happened in Ken's code.
>=
 
> 2) Is the approach of defining a node by its position flawed? 
> 
>

> Phill
